Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research ARTS: Integrative Research and Training in Tropical Taxonomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Taxonomy, the science of finding, describing and naming organisms, is vital to biological research and conservation of life's diversity. The on-going effort to survey, inventory, and preserve the ocean's biological diversity is threatened by a shortage of taxonomic expertise. Although focused on Caribbean biodiversity, the overarching goal of this project is to promote conservation of marine biodiversity around the world. This project will make it easier to correctly identify and document marine biodiversity, to detect invasive species, and to protect rare and endangered species by training new taxonomists, by developing Internet-based resources to support taxonomic research, and by making taxonomic methods easily accessible to non-specialists. This project will create new taxonomic descriptions and revisions of currently undescribed species from the Caribbean, which will be immediately useful to any researcher, manager, or conservation practitioner working in the region, and will contribute to the species inventory of the Caribbean. Open-access videos and how-to guides will allow specialists to convey enthusiasm for these organisms to the public, to managers, and to policy makers, and provide a way for students and the general public to learn more about taxonomy.

This project has three parts with complementary aims. Part A will document the biodiversity of 6 groups of marine organisms with high, but poorly known, diversity in the Southern Caribbean (sponges, hydroids, sea anemones, sea squirts, ribbon worms, and seaweeds). This work will emphasize the integration of traditional morphological and molecular characters with non-traditional characters such as larval morphology, live coloration, and characters derived from confocal and electron microscopy. Established experts will work closely with experts-in-training, with a focus on species from the Caribbean coast of Panama that are known to be in particular need of taxonomic revision. Part B will provide training workshops for graduate students and junior researchers interested in developing taxonomic expertise in one of 6 focal groups; enabling them to (1) identify species in the field, (2) efficiently collect and preserve material for subsequent taxonomic work, (3) use existing keys or monographs to identify material to species, and (4) develop personal connections with a global network of other students and specialists. Part C will make the basic skills and vocabulary involved in the taxonomy of all 6 groups globally accessible to both expert and non-specialist workers in biodiversity and conservation. This part will develop a standard package of internet-based tools for each group, including a set of how-to videos and illustrated definitions of technical terms, with translations into several languages. This toolkit will be designed to facilitate rapid biodiversity documentation and to increase the precision of preliminary field identifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of species on Earth remain undescribed. This means we lack the baseline knowledge to monitor how ecosystems respond to climate change, and to inform conservation priorities, and sustainable use of biodiversity. One of the major challenges to describing biodiversity is the shortage of taxonomic expertise relative to the number of undescribed and undiscovered taxa. The goal of this collaborative project was to promote knowledge and conservation of understudied marine organisms by increasing taxonomic expertise, and to make access to taxonomic methods easier by providing resources for non-specialists. PI Maslakova was responsible for the research and training on nemertean biology and systematics. Nemertean worms remain one of the lesser known invertebrate phyla despite their diversity, importance as predators in marine ecosystems, biomedical potential as producers of diverse toxins, and significance of some species to fisheries as predators, parasites, or nuisance of commercially harvested crustaceans, mollusks and fish. 

The specific aims of this project were: 

  1. To characterize the nemertean diversity of Bocas del Toro, Panama, and the broader Caribbean region.
  2. To integrate research with taxonomic training by a) engaging undergraduate and graduate students in research, and b) offering a Nemertean Taxonomy Workshop at the Smithsonian Tropica Research Institute?s Research Station at Bocas del Toro, Panama.
  3. To increase global access to nemertean taxonomy by producing illustrated materials, 'how-to' videos, and content for a multilingual glossary of taxonomic terms (TaxaGloss). 

All three specific aims of the project were successfully carried out: 

Aim 1. Approximately 38 described nemertean species were previously reported from the Caribbean region (7 from Bocas). This research reveled that the actual diversity in the Caribbean is more than five times that number (much more for Bocas). Sampling and DNA-barcoding carried out with support from this grant added 153 nemertean species to the fauna of the Caribbean Sea. Adding to this number species revealed by other recent research (published or unpublished) brings the number of nemertean species in the Caribbean to 203. About 90% of these species are undescribed, and most species we found are cryptic (i.e. they possess one or more morphological look-alikes in the region, which are genetically distinct). We still expect to find more species. One manuscript reporting the newly discovered diversity is in preparation, and three manuscripts are in preparation formally describing 12 of the new species from three different genera. We are also working on the first of a kind illustrated identification guide to nemerteans of the Caribbean (the draft currently encompasses 178 species). Formally describing all of the diversity we discovered is outside the scope of this project. The discovery of a surprisingly large number of cryptic species complexes spurred a new line of research on the history and mechanisms of speciation by the Ph.D. student supported by the project. 

Aim 2. With the support from this project Maslakova recruited and trained a new Ph.D. student, organized and co-taught a 10-day Nemertean Taxonomy workshop at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute?s (STRI) station at Bocas del Toro, Panama (14 students from 10 different countries), and engaged in this research four summer REU interns (including two from underrepresented categories), and 11 other undergraduates (as part of her regular teaching at the University of Oregon). The Ph.D. student and two of the undergraduates presented results at a national conference. One REU intern completed an honor?s thesis at her institution based on her research on this project. A supplemental ROA award helped support research by Dr. Megan Schwartz (University of Washington and University of Puget Sound) and several undergraduate students in her lab. The Nemertean Taxonomy workshop helped to connect new and established nemertean researchers from around the world, and spurred multiple collaborations. 

Aim 3. In collaboration with a STRI videographer and a professional illustrator Maslakova produced 1) six ?how to? videos that illustrate methods of collecting, preserving and studying nemerteans, and 2) illustrations for the identification guide to Nemerteans of the Caribbean. Maslakova also created content (photographs, character definitions, translations) for the Nemertean section of the TaxaGloss, a multilingual on-line glossary of taxonomic terms.
